
## Suggested solutions for Chapter 2

## Problem 1

Draw good diagrams of saturated hydrocarbons with seven carbon atoms having (a) mean, (b) branched, and (c) tycks frameworks. Draw molecules based on each framework having both ketone and carboxylic adic functional groups.

## Purpose of the problem

To get you drawing simple structures well and to steer you away from rules and names towards creative structural ideas.

## Suggested solution

There is only one linear saturated hydrocarbon with seven carbon atoms but there is a wide choice for the rest. We offer some possibilities but you may well have thought of others.

Study the structure of brevelosis on a. 33. Make a list of the different types of functional group (you already know that there are many effect and of the numbers of range of different states. Finally, study the carbon framework - is in linear, cyclic, or branched?

## Purpose of the problem

To persuade you that functional groups are easily recognized even in complicated molecules and that, say, an ester is an ester whatever company it may keep. You were not expected to see the full implications of the carbon framework part of the question. That was to amuse and surprise you.

## Suggested solution

The ethers are all the unmarked oxygen atoms in the rings: all are cyclic, seven in six-membered rings, two in seven-membered rings, and one in an eight-membered ring. There are two carbonyl groups, one an ester and one an aldehyde, and three alkenes.

## Problem 4

Draw structures corresponding to these names. In each case suggest alternative names that might convey the structure more clearly to someone who is listening to you speak.

(a) 1,4-di-(1,1-dimethylethyl)benzene

(b) 3-(prop-2-enyloxy)prop-1-ene

(c) cyclohexa-1,3,5-triene

## Suggested solution

There are,of course,many possible solutions. \( \mathrm{X} \) could be a heteroatom or a structural fragment while Ar could be any of a very large number of substituted benzene rings or even other types of aromatic rings. ## Suggested solutions for Chapter 3

## Problem 1

How does the mass spectrum gives evidence of isotopes in the compounds of bromine, onlorine, and carbon? Assuming the molecular ion of each of these compounds is of 100% abundance, what peaks (and in what intensity) would appear around that mass number? (a) \( {\mathrm{C}}_{5}{\mathrm{H}}_{5}\mathrm{{BrO}} \) ,(b) \( {\mathrm{C}}_{60} \) ,(c) \( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}{\mathrm{H}}_{4}\mathrm{{BrCl}} \) ? Give in cases (a) and (c) a possible structure for the compound. What compound is (b)?

## Purpose of the problem

To give you practice in spotting the important atoms that have isotopes and in interpreting multiple molecular ions. The molecular ion is the most important peak in the mass spectrum and is often the acty peak to interest us.

## Suggested solution

Bromine has two isotopes, \( {}^{79}\mathrm{{Br}} \) and \( {}^{81}\mathrm{{Br}} \) ,in about a 1:1 ratio,chlorine has two, \( {}^{35}\mathrm{{Cl}} \) and \( {}^{37}\mathrm{{Cl}} \) ,in about a 3:1 ratio and there is about \( {1.1}\% {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) in normal compounds. Hence the molecular ions of \( \rightarrow \) three compounds will be as follows.

a’ \( {\mathrm{C}}_{2}{\mathrm{H}}_{5}\mathrm{{BrO}} \) ,MW 124/126. There will also be weak peaks (2.2% of each main peak) at 125 and 127 for the same ions with \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) .

---

- Compounds containing \( \mathrm{{Br}} \) or \( \mathrm{{Cl}} \) should have their molecular ions specified like this. The first figure gives \( {\mathrm{M}}^{ + } \) with \( {}^{79}\mathrm{{Br}} \) and the second with \( {}^{81}\mathrm{{Br}} \) .

---

b: \( {\mathrm{C}}_{60} \) has a molecular ion at 720 with a strong peak at 721 . The chance that one \( \mathrm{C} \) atom is \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) is simply \( {60} \times  {1.1}\%  = {66}\% \) so the \( \mathrm{M} + 1 \) peak is more than half as strong as \( {\mathrm{M}}^{ + } \) itself. The chance of two \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) atoms is small.

c) \( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}{\mathrm{H}}_{4}\mathrm{{BrCl}} \) is more complicated as the molecular ion will contain a 1:1 ratio of \( {}^{79}\mathrm{{Br}} \) and \( {}^{81}\mathrm{{Br}} \) ,and a 3:1 ratio of \( {}^{35}\mathrm{{Cl}} \) and \( {}^{37}\mathrm{{Cl}} \) . The molecular ion consists of four peaks (ratios in brackets): \( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}{\mathrm{H}}_{4}^{79}{\mathrm{{Br}}}^{35}\mathrm{{Cl}} \) (3), \( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}{\mathrm{H}}_{4}^{81}{\mathrm{{Br}}}^{35}\mathrm{{Cl}} \) (3), \( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}{\mathrm{H}}_{4}^{79}{\mathrm{{Br}}}^{37}\mathrm{{Cl}} \) (1),and \( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}{\mathrm{H}}_{4}^{81}{\mathrm{{Br}}}^{37}\mathrm{{Cl}} \) (1). The masses of these peaks are 190, 192, 192, and 194. The molecular ion will therefore have three peaks at 190, 192, and 194 in a ratio of 3:4:1 with peaks at 191,193,and 195 at \( 6 \times  {1.1}\%  = {6.6}\% \) of the peak before it. So the complete picture is 190 (75%), 191 (5%), 192 (100%), 193 (6.6%), 194 (25%), and 195 (1.7%).

Compound (b) is, of course, buckminsterfullerene and the other compounds might be isomers such as these.

## Purpose of the problem

To familiarize you with the four main regions of the \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) NMR spectrum: saturated carbons at 0-50 p.p.m., saturated carbons next to oxygen at 50-100 p.p.m., alkenes and aromatic compounds with unsaturated carbon at \( {100} - {150} \) p.p.m.,and unsaturated carbon next to oxygen (usually \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) ) at \( {150} - {200} \) p.p.m.

## Suggested solution

There are four different types of carbon atom in the benzene ring (don't forget the 'ipso' carbon joined to the substituent) and it is not easy to say which is which. The rest can be deduced from the four main regions.

## Problem 3

The thinner used in typists’ correction fluids is a single compound, \( {\mathrm{C}}_{2}{\mathrm{H}}_{3}{\mathrm{{Cl}}}_{3} \) ,having \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) NMR peaks at 45.1 and 95.0 p.p.m. What is its structure? A commercial paint thinner gives two spots on chromatography and has \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) NMR peaks at 7.0,27.5,35.2,45.3,95.6,and 206.3 p.p.m. Suggest what compounds might be used to make up this thinner.

## Purpose of the problem

To start you on the road of structure identification with one very simple problem and then some deductive reasoning. It is necessary to think about the size of chemical shifts in this case.

## Suggested solution

There are only two possible structures for a compound \( {\mathrm{C}}_{2}{\mathrm{H}}_{3}{\mathrm{{Cl}}}_{3} \) - it must be trichloroethane and the chlorines can be distributed in these two ways.

<!-- Media -->

`C(C(Cl)Cl)Cl.CC(Cl)(Cl)Cl`

<!-- Media -->

---

- We have ignored the effects of the \( \mathrm{{Cl}} \) atoms on the other \( \mathrm{C} \) atom, but they will also increase the chemical shift to a lesser extent.

---

The first isomer would have a peak for the methyl group in the region 0-50 p.p.m. and one for the \( {\mathrm{{CCl}}}_{3} \) group at a much larger chemical shift because of the three chlorine atoms. The second isomer would have a peak for \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2}\mathrm{{Cl}} \) in the \( {50} - {100} \) p.p.m. region and one for \( {\mathrm{{CHCl}}}_{2} \) at a larger shift but the two shifts would not be so far apart. The observed shifts are 50 p.p.m. apart and, in fact, the compound is 1,1,1-trichloroethane. The NMR spectrum of the 1,1,2-trichloro isomer has peaks at 50.5 and 70.7 p.p.m. - much closer together.

The mixture probably contains the same trichloroethane as the peaks at 45.3 and 95.6 p.p.m. suggest (the chemical shifts of the mixture need not be quite the same as those of the pure compound as each compound is effectively dissolved in the other). The remaining peaks at 7.0, 27.3, 35.2, and 206.3 p.p.m. definitely belong to a carbonyl compound, probably a ketone since 206.3 p.p.m. is so large. Butanone fits the bill as it has one methyl and one \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2} \) group on the carbonyl group and one methyl away from any electronegative atoms. There are other possibilities.

## Problem 4

The ’normal’ O-H stretch (i.e. without hydrogen bonding) comes at about \( {3600}{\mathrm{\;{cm}}}^{-1} \) . What is the reduced mass \( \left( \mu \right) \) for \( \mathrm{O} - \mathrm{H} \) ? What happens to the reduced mass when you double the atomic weight of each atom in turn,that is,what is \( \mu \) for \( \mathrm{O} - \mathrm{D} \) and what is \( \mu \) for \( \mathrm{S} - \mathrm{H} \) ? In fact, both \( \mathrm{O} - \mathrm{D} \) and \( \mathrm{S} - \mathrm{H} \) stretches come at about \( {2500}{\mathrm{\;{cm}}}^{-1} \) . Why?

## Purpose of the problem

To get you thinking about the position of IR bands in terms of the two main influences - reduced mass and bond strength. The relationship between the frequency(v)of the vibration,

the force constant \( f \) (more or less equals bond strength),and the reduced mass \( \left( \mu \right) \) is given by mes equation.

\[v = \frac{1}{2\pi c}\sqrt{\frac{f}{\mu }}\]

## Suggested solution

The reduced mass \( \left( \mu \right) \) of a vibrating bond is given by this equation.

\[\mu  = \frac{{m}_{1}{m}_{2}}{{m}_{1} + {m}_{2}}\]

Sc She reduced mass of \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) is \( {16}/{17} \) or about 0.94 . When you double the mass of \( \mathrm{H} \) ,the reduced mass of OD becomes \( {32}/{18} \) or about 1.78 which is roughly double that for OH. But when you simple the mass of \( \mathrm{O} \) ,the reduced mass for \( \mathrm{{SH}} \) is \( {32}/{33} \) or about0.97- hardly changed from \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) ! The change in reduced mass is enough to account for the changed frequency of the OD bond - it showers by about \( \sqrt{2} \) - but cannot account for the change from \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) to \( \mathrm{{SH}} \) as the two reduced ames are about the same. The only explanation of this can be that the \( \mathrm{{SH}} \) bond is weaker than the CH bond by a factor of about 2.

There is an important principle to be deduced from this problem. Very roughly, the reduced masses of all bonds involving heavier atoms (C, N, O, S, etc.) are about the same and the differences in IR mething frequency are mostly due to changes in bond strength. This is most dramatic in comparing Jule, double, and triple bonds. Only with bonds involving hydrogen does the reduced mass become the more important factor, though it is also significant in comparing, say, C-O with C-Cl.

## Problem 8

<!-- Media -->

`CC(C)(C)O.CC#N.CC#N.[CH3-].[CH3-].[K+].[Y]`

<!-- Media -->

The situation is as follows. You have dissolved \( t - \mathrm{{BuOH}}\left( {{\mathrm{{Me}}}_{3}\mathrm{{COH}}}\right) \) in \( \mathrm{{MeCN}} \) with an acid catalyst, left the solution overnight, and found crystals with the following characteristics there in the morning. What are they?

IR: 3435 and \( {1686}{\mathrm{\;{cm}}}^{-1} \) ; \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) NMR: 169,50,29,and 25 p.p.m.; mass spectrum (%): 115 (7), 100 (10), 64 (5), 60 (21), 59 (17), 58 (100), and 56 (7). (Don't try to assign all of these!)

## Purpose of the problem

Structure determination in real life. This is a common situation - you carry out a reaction and you find a product that is not starting material - what is it? You need to use all the information and some logic. What you must not do is decide what the product is from your (limited) knowledge of chemistry and then make the data fit this structure.

## Suggested solution

The mass spectrum shows that the compound has a molecular ion at 115 and is presumably \( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}{\mathrm{H}}_{13}\mathrm{{NO}} \) - the sum of the two reagents \( t \) -BuOH and MeCN. It appears that they have added together but the infrared tells us that neither \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) nor \( \mathrm{{CN}} \) has survived. So what do we know?

- The IR spectrum shows that we have an \( \mathrm{{NH}} \) group and a \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) group,which accounts for both heteroatoms.

- The NMR spectrum shows a carbonyl group (169 p.p.m.) and three types of saturated carbon atom. There must be a lot of symmetry and one explanation might be that the \( t \) -Bu group has survived. This would give us \( \mathrm{{NH}},\mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) ,and \( {\mathrm{{Me}}}_{3}\mathrm{C} \) as three fragments and would leave \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{3} \) left over. We can join these fragments up in two ways.

<!-- Media -->

`CC(C)(C)C(=O)NC.CC(=O)NC(C)(C)C.[Ba].[Ba]`

<!-- Media -->

Each of these structures has four types of carbon atom and could fit the spectra. We might prefer \( 8\mathrm{\;b} \) as the \( \mathrm{{Me}} - \mathrm{C} - \mathrm{N} \) group is still present but a better decision is taken using the mass spectrum fragmentation pattern. The peak at 100 is the loss of 15 (Me) which could occur from either structure,though more typical of \( 8\mathrm{\;b} \) . The base peak (100%) at 58 suggests \( {\mathrm{{Me}}}_{2}\mathrm{C} = {\mathrm{{NH}}}_{2}^{ + } \) ,which can easily come from \( 8\mathrm{\;b} \) but could come from \( 8\mathrm{a} \) only with extensive reorganization of the skeleton. The correct structure is \( 8\mathrm{\;b} \) ,though to be certain we really need \( {}^{1}\mathrm{H} \) NMR too (Chapter 11).

## Problem 9

How many isomers of trichlorobenzene are there? The 1,2,3-trichloro isomer is illustrated. Could they be distinguished by \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) NMR?

## Purpose of the problem

To get you thinking about the possible different structures answering one formula as detemined, say, by the mass spectrum. It is important not to stop trying when you have deduced one possible structure for a set of data but to continue thinking about alternatives. This exercise should help and should also make you think about symmetry.

## Suggested solution

If two of the \( \mathrm{{Cl}} \) atoms are next to each other (’ortho’) there are two possible places for the third giving the 1,2,3- and 1,2,4-isomers. If the first two are 1,3-related ('meta') there are again two structures but we have just used one of them (the 1,2,4-isomer). If the first two are placed 1,4 ’para’) there is only one place for the third and we have already found that (the 1,2,4-isomer). There are three isomers in all.

## Purpose of the problem

To show you that fragmentation in the mass spectrum is sometimes useful.

## Suggested solution

The three compounds are isomers, \( {\mathrm{C}}_{5}{\mathrm{H}}_{10}\mathrm{O} \) ,and have the same molecular ion at 86 .

Fragmentation of ketones usually occurs next to the \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) group to give first an acylium ion and then, by loss of CO, a carbocation. The fragment ions are different in the three cases. The first compound might lose the methyl or propyl side chains and give two series of fragment ions. # Suggested solutions for Chapter 4

## Problem 1

In the (notional and best avoided in practice) formation of \( \mathrm{{NaCl}} \) from a sodium atom and a chlorine atom, descriptions like this abound in textbooks: 'an electron is transferred from the valency shell of the sodium atom to the valency shell of the chlorine atom'. What is meant, in quantum number terms, by 'valency shell'? Give a complete description in terms of all four quantum numbers of that transferred electron: (a) while it is in the sodium atom and (b) after it has been transferred to the chlorine atom. Why is the formation of \( \mathrm{{NaCl}} \) by this process to be discouraged?

## Purpose of the problem

To encourage you to use the periodic table in working out the electronic configuration of atoms and to familiarize you with the four quantum numbers.

## Suggested solution

Sodium and chlorine are at either end of the second row of the periodic table: Na, Mg, Al, Si, P, S, \( \mathrm{{Cl}} \) ,Ar. Sodium is in group 1 and has the configuration \( 1{\mathrm{\;s}}^{2},2{\mathrm{\;s}}^{2},2{\mathrm{p}}^{6},3{\mathrm{\;s}}^{1} \) . Chlorine is in group VII (17) and has the configuration \( 1{s}^{2},2{s}^{2},2{p}^{6},3{s}^{2},3{p}^{5} \) . The ’valency shell’ refers to the outer shell of the atom where all the chemistry occurs and is known by the value of the principal quantum number(n)for that shell. This is the number at the front of the electronic description: in this case ( \( \mathrm{{Na}} \) or \( \mathrm{{Cl}} \) ) the electrons are in \( 3\mathrm{\;s} \) or \( 3\mathrm{p} \) orbitals so \( n = 3 \) .

While the electron is on the sodium atom it is a \( 3\mathrm{\;s} \) electron,that is, \( n = 3;l = 0 \) . There is only one type of s orbital so \( {m}_{l} \) must also be 0 . The spin is arbitrarily up or down so it doesn’t matter whether you say \( {m}_{s} =  - \frac{1}{2} \) or \( + \frac{1}{2} \) . When the electron is transferred to the chlorine atom it goes into a \( 3{\mathrm{p}}_{z} \) orbital so we have \( n = 3 \) again but now \( l = 1 \) (p orbital), \( {m}_{l} \) is \( 1\left( {\mathrm{p}}_{z}\right. \) orbital),and again \( {m}_{s} =  - \frac{1}{2} \) or \( + \frac{1}{2} \) . If any of this gave you trouble,you should refer to the chapter.

This method of making sodium chloride is to be discouraged because both elements are extremely reactive and would combine with an enormous release of energy. This is, of course, because the odd electron on sodium is much more stable if it is transferred to chlorine. We are more likely to make sodium and chlorine from abundant \( \mathrm{{NaCl}} \) - there’s plenty in the sea,for example.

## Problem 2

What is the electronic structure of these species? You should consult a periodic table before answering.

\[\text{HO HS}{}^{ \ominus  }\;\text{HS}{}^{ \oplus  }\;\text{Xe}\]

## Purpose of the problem

To encourage you to use the periodic table in working out the electronic configuration of atoms. We really mean it!

---

- This factor was used in Chapter 3 (p. 68) to explain the relative positions of the stretching frequencies of \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) , \( \mathrm{{NH}} \) ,and \( \mathrm{{CH}} \) in the infrared spectrum.

---

## Suggested solution

\( {\mathrm{H}}^{ - } \) Hydrogen is the first element in the periodic table and has just one proton in the nucleus and just one orbital (1s) available to be filled. If we fill it, we get a species with one proton and two electrons and that is \( {\mathrm{H}}^{ - } \) . The answer is \( 1{\mathrm{\;s}}^{2} \) .

\( {\mathrm{{HS}}}^{ - } \) Sulfur is in group VI (16) in the same row as \( \mathrm{{Na}} \) and \( \mathrm{{Cl}} \) . It makes a \( \sigma \) bond to hydrogen and uses the remainder of the electrons as lone pairs to give a full noble gas configuration (same as Ar) of: \( 1{\mathrm{\;s}}^{2},2{\mathrm{\;s}}^{2},2{\mathrm{p}}^{6},3{\mathrm{\;s}}^{2},3{\mathrm{p}}^{6} \) .

Potassium is below sodium in the periodic table so this cation has lost its 4s electron and is: \( 1{s}^{2},2{s}^{2},2{p}^{6},3{s}^{2},3{p}^{6} \) . This configuration is the same as that of \( {\mathrm{{Cl}}}^{ - } \) .

Xe Xenon is a noble gas in group VIII (18). It comes some way down the table after He, Ne, Ar, and \( \mathrm{{Kr}} \) and after two rows of transition elements that fill the \( 3\mathrm{\;d} \) and \( 4\mathrm{\;d} \) orbitals so it has \( 1{\mathrm{\;s}}^{2} \) , \( 2{s}^{2},2{p}^{6},3{s}^{2},3{p}^{6},4{s}^{2},3{d}^{10},4{p}^{6},5{s}^{2},4{d}^{10},5{p}^{6} \) .

## Problem 3

What sort of bonds can be formed between \( s \) orbitals and \( p \) orbitals? Which will provide better overlap, \( 1\mathrm{\;s} + 2\mathrm{p} \) or \( 1\mathrm{\;s} + 3\mathrm{p} \) ? Which bonds will be stronger,those between hydrogen and \( \mathrm{C},\mathrm{N},\mathrm{O} \) ,and \( \mathrm{F} \) on the one hand or those between hydrogen and \( \mathrm{{Si}},\mathrm{P},\mathrm{S} \) ,and \( \mathrm{{Cl}} \) on the other? Within the first group,bond strength goes in this order: \( \mathrm{{HF}} > \mathrm{{OH}} > \mathrm{{NH}} > \mathrm{{CH}} \) . Why?

## Purpose of the problem

To encourage you to think about the energies of orbitals as well as just about their quantum description.

## Suggested solution

\( \mathrm{s} \) orbitals and \( \mathrm{p} \) orbitals can combine to form \( \sigma \) bonds. In the chapter (p. 108) we discussed the structure of \( {\mathrm{{PH}}}_{3} \) which has bond angles of about \( {90}^{ \circ  } \) and is made of \( \sigma \) bonds between \( 1\mathrm{\;s}\left( \mathrm{H}\right) \) and 3p(P) orbitals. There is no special problem in overlapping either \( 2\mathrm{p} \) or \( 3\mathrm{p} \) orbitals with 1s orbitals though the \( 3\mathrm{p} \) orbitals are larger.

<!-- Media -->

<!-- Media -->

The difference comes in the energy of the orbitals. The \( 2\mathrm{p} \) orbitals are much closer in energy to the \( 1\mathrm{\;s} \) orbital than the \( 3\mathrm{p} \) orbitals and so the energy gain is greater on \( \sigma \) bond formation.

Bonds between \( \mathrm{H} \) and \( \mathrm{C},\mathrm{N},\mathrm{O} \) ,and \( \mathrm{F} \) are all stronger than bonds between \( \mathrm{H} \) and \( \mathrm{{Si}},\mathrm{P},\mathrm{S} \) ,and \( \mathrm{{Cl}} \) . This is partly because \( 2\mathrm{{pAOs}} \) are used for the first but \( 3\mathrm{{pAOs}} \) for the second group. The full story includes the fact that \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{4},{\mathrm{{NH}}}_{3} \) ,and \( {\mathrm{H}}_{2}\mathrm{O} \) are hybridized (so the lower energy 2s orbitals are used as well) while \( {\mathrm{{PH}}}_{3} \) and \( {\mathrm{H}}_{2}\mathrm{\;S} \) are not hybridized. \( {\mathrm{{SiH}}}_{4} \) is,of course,tetrahedral while it is difficult to say whether linear \( \mathrm{{HF}} \) and \( \mathrm{{HCl}} \) are hybridized or not!

Within the group \( \mathrm{C},\mathrm{N},\mathrm{O} \) ,and \( \mathrm{F} \) ,the energy of the 1s orbital stays the same but the energy of the \( 2\mathrm{p} \) (or of the \( {\mathrm{{sp}}}^{3} \) hybrid orbitals) drops as the elements get more electronegative. These orbitals get closer in energy to the 1s orbital and the gain in bond formation is correspondingly greater.

- If you said that this species is hybridized and put electrons into \( 3{\mathrm{{sp}}}^{3} \) orbitals you have done well. This answer is right too.

## Problem 4

Though no helium ’molecule’ \( {\mathrm{{He}}}_{2} \) exists,an ion \( {\mathrm{{He}}}_{2}^{ + } \) does exist. Explain.

## Purpose of the problem

To encourage you to think about the filling of atomic orbitals and to accept surprising conclusions.

## Suggested solution

The orbitals of the \( \mathrm{{He}} \) atom and the fact that no \( {\mathrm{{He}}}_{2} \) molecule exists are discussed in the book on pp. 97-8. The problem is that the 1 s orbitals overlap to form a bonding \( \left( \sigma \right) \) and an antibonding \( \left( {\sigma }^{ * }\right) \) orbital but both would be filled in the \( {\mathrm{{He}}}_{2} \) molecule and the bond order is zero. If there is one fewer electron,only one electron need go into the antibonding orbital \( \left( {\sigma }^{ > }\right) \) and there is a bond order of one-half. The ion \( {\mathrm{{He}}}_{3}^{ + } \) does exist.

## Problem 6

Construct an MO diagram for the molecule LiH and suggest what type of bond it might have.

## Purpose of the problem

To demonstrate that a simple MO treatment can be applied to ionic as well as covalent structures.

## Suggested solution

\( \mathrm{H} \) has,of course,only one electron in a 1s orbital. Li has three - a full 1s shell and one electron in the \( 2\mathrm{\;s} \) orbital. Li is also very electropositive so its \( 2\mathrm{\;s} \) orbital is high in energy (much higher than that of F - see the answer to Problem 3). The result is that lithium gives its 2s electron to the 1s orbital of \( \mathrm{H} \) and an ionic compound results with both ions having the same electronic configuration: \( 1{\mathrm{\;s}}^{2} \) . The hydrides of the alkali metals are useful sources of hydride ion \( \left( {\mathrm{H}}^{ - }\right) \) .

## Problem 7

Deduce the MOs for the oxygen molecule. What is the bond order in oxygen and where are the \( {2p} \) electrons?

<!-- Media -->

## Purpose of the problem

To let you try out your skill in a simple diatomic molecule that has a curious structure.

## Suggested solution

Simply dock two oxygen atoms side by side and overlap the orbitals. The 1s and 2s (only the 2s is shown below) interact as usual but both bonding and antibonding MOs are occupied so there is no bonding. When we overlap the partly filled \( \mathrm{p} \) AOs we find we can make three bonds - one \( 2\mathrm{{p\sigma }} \) and two \( 2\mathrm{p}\pi \) bonds. Now we have two electrons left over and they have to go into antibonding \( 2{\mathrm{{p\pi }}}^{ * } \) MOs. The first two up are degenerate so it is better to put one electron in each and avoid the repulsion from two electrons in the same orbital.

---

You should note that oxygen has four \( 2\mathrm{p} \) electrons and it will have two in one \( p \) orbital and one each in the other two to avoid repulsion.

## Purpose of the problem

## Suggested solution

Here we have two cations,two compounds with \( \pi \) bonds,and two with nothing but \( \sigma \) bonds. ## Problem 2

Cyclopropanone exists as the hydrate in water but 2-hydroxyethanal does not exist as its hemiacetal. Explain.

<!-- Media -->

`C1CC1(O)O.C1CC1(O)O.C1CC1=O.C(C(=O)[O-])O.[K+].O.O.O.O.O.O.O.O`

<!-- Media -->

## Purpose of the problem

To get you thinking about equilibria and hence stability of compounds rather than reaction mechanisms.

## Suggested solution

Hydration is an equilibrium reaction so the mechanism is not strictly relevant to the question. If you have drawn the mechanism, you should be proud rather than ashamed because it is an important mechanism. To answer the question we must consider the effect of the three-membered ring. All three-membered rings are unstable because the ring angles are about \( {60}^{ \circ  } \) instead of the usual angle. Cyclopropanone is very strained because the trigonal \( \left( {\mathrm{{sp}}}^{2}\right) \) carbon would like an angle of \( {120}^{ \circ  } \) and there is \( {60}^{ \circ  } \) of strain’. In the hydrate the trigonal carbon is tetrahedral \( \left( {\mathrm{{sp}}}^{3}\right) \) and there is only ' 49 of strain'. The hydrate is more stable than the ketone.

The second case is totally different. The hydroxy-aldehyde is not strained but the hemiacetal has \( {49}^{ \circ  } \) of strain at each corner. Even without strain,hydrates and hemiacetals are normally less stable than aldehydes or ketones because one \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) bond is worth more than two \( \mathrm{C} - \mathrm{O} \) single bonds. In this case the hemiacetal is even less stable because of strain.

## Purpose of the problem

To let you think practically about reactions that may give more than one product.

## Suggested solution

The three compounds are easily drawn: one or other \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) or both may be reduced. hydroxy-ketone

The diol has no \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) group in the \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) NMR or infrared and has a molecular ion in the mass spectrum at two mass units higher than the other two products. Distinguishing them is more tricky. The hydroxy-ketone has a conjugated carbonyl group (about \( {1680}{\mathrm{\;{cm}}}^{-1} \) in the infrared) but the hydroxy-aldehyde is not conjugated (about \( {1730}{\mathrm{\;{cm}}}^{-1} \) in the infrared). The chemical shift of the \( \mathrm{C} - \mathrm{{OH}} \) carbon atoms in the 100-150 p.p.m. region will also be different because the benzene ring is next to this atom in the hydroxy-ketone. Calculations from tables in Williams and Fleming suggest about 80 p.p.m. for the hydroxy-ketone and about 60 p.p.m. for the hydroxy-aldehyde. The mass spectra will also be different - simple \( \alpha \) -cleavage gives quite different fragments.

## Problem 5

The triketone shown here is called 'ninhydrin' and is used for the detection of amino acids. It exists in aqueous solution as a monohydrate. Which of the three ketones is hydrated and why?

## Purpose of the problem

To start you thinking about why some carbonyl groups are more stable than others.

<!-- Media -->

`C1=CC2=C(C=C1)C(=O)C(C2=O)(O)O`

## Suggested solution

The two ketones next to the benzene ring are conjugated with it and thereby stabilized though they are also destabilized by the middle carbonyl group - two electron-withdrawing groups next to each other is a bad thing. The central carbonyl group has no stabilization from the benzene ring and a double dose of destabilization from its neighbours.

<!-- Media -->

Draw a full orbital diagram for all the bonding and antibonding \( \pi \) orbitals in the three-membered cyclic cation shown here. The molecule is obviously very strained. Might it survive by also being aromatic?

## Purpose of the problem

Revision of MO diagrams for conjugated systems with aromaticity.

## Suggested solution

There are only two electrons in this simple cation but we need to mix the \( \pi \) bond \( \left( \pi \right. \) and \( \left. {{\pi }^{ * }\text{orbitals}}\right) \) with the empty \( p \) orbital to give the MOs. One MO will be bonding all round the ring and this is the only one that matters to the structure. The others may have given you problems. We can mix the pAO with the \( \pi  - \mathrm{{MO}} \) as they have the same symmetry in a three-membered ring but we cannot mix p with \( {\pi }^{ * } \) . So our three MOs are \( \pi  + p,\pi  - p \) ,and \( {\pi }^{ * } \) .

<!-- Media -->

<!-- figureText: \( \pi  - \mathrm{{MOs}} \) of the alkene \( p - {AO} \) of the cation -->

``

<!-- Media -->

The cyclic cation is stable and can be made because of the gain in energy in populating only the lowest ali-bonding orbital. As it happens \( {\Psi }_{2} \) and \( {\Psi }_{3} \) are degenerate. If you count the number of bonding and antibonding interactions in each you will see that the net result is one antibonding interaction in both orbitals. It is also aromatic,having \( {4n} + {2\pi } \) -electrons where \( n = 0 \) .

You get the same result if you mix three p-AOs, one on each carbon atom. Then it is easier if we look down on the ring showing the top lobe of the p orbital at each atom. The lowest, all-bonding orbital has no nodes (except the plane of the ring) and the two degenerate, antibonding, and unoccupied orbitals have one node each.

## Purpose of the problem

To get you thinking about the relationship between conjugation and light absorption.

## Suggested solution

Each dyestuff has essentially the same conjugated system shown here isolated from extra substituents. The positive charge is shared between the two nitrogen atoms and the whole system is symmetrical. The colour is due to excitation of the lone pair electrons, which are delocalized over the whole system,into an antibonding \( {\pi }^{ * } \) orbital of the aromatic system. There will be many bonding \( \pi \) orbitals and the same number of antibonding \( {\pi }^{ * } \) orbitals. The lowest (the LUMO) will be unusually low in energy and the \( \mathrm{n},{\pi }^{ * } \) is in the visible region.

<!-- Media -->

`C[N+](C)(C)C1=CC=C(C=C1)C=C2C=CC(=[N+](C)C)C=C2.C[N+](C)(C)C1=CC=C(C=C1)C=C2C=CC(=[N+](C)C)C=C2.C[N+](C)(C)C1=CC=C(C=C1)C=C2C=CC(=[N+](C)C)C=C2.[I-].[I-].[I-].[I-].[I-].[I-]`

<!-- Media -->

The substituent on the middle atom is different in the two dyes and is also conjugating. This extra conjugation decides the exact shade of colour with the highly conjugating naphthalene ring in E142 taking the absorption all the way through to red light so the dye appears green to the eye. The \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) group also helps as a lone pair is also conjugated into the aromatic rings. The sulfonate groups make the compound water-soluble.

The orange and yellow compounds owe their colour to functionality. 'Orange' is a quinone - a conjugated six-membered ring compound with four electrons - and has a low-energy unoccupied orbital (a \( {\pi }^{ * } \) orbital,the LUMO) from the two conjugated carbonyl groups,which is easily occupied by excitation of a \( \pi \) electron. ’Yellow’ is diazomethane,an unstable toxic and even explosive gas. which has some conjugation in its very small framework but owes its colour mainly to the \( \mathrm{N} = \mathrm{N} \) functionality which again has a low-energy \( {\pi }^{ * } \) orbital.

## Problem 1

If you wanted to separate a mixture of naphthalene,pyridine,and \( p \) -toluic acid,how would you go about it?

<!-- Media -->

`C1=CC2=C(C=C1)C=CC=C2.CC1=CC=C(C=C1)C(=O)O.CCCCCCCCC.CCCCCCCCC.CCCCCCCCC.CCCCCCCCC`

<!-- Media -->

## Purpose of the problem

Revision of simple acidity and basicity in a practical situation.

## Suggested solution

Pyridine is a weak base \( \left( {\mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}}{5.5}}\right) \) and can be dissolved in aqueous acid. \( p \) -Toluic acid is a weak acid ( \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) about 4.5) and can be dissolved in aqueous base. Naphthalene is neither an acid nor a base and remains insoluble in water at any \( \mathrm{{pH}} \) . So,dissolve the mixture in an organic solvent immiscible with water (say ether, \( {\mathrm{{Et}}}_{2}\mathrm{O} \) ,or \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2}{\mathrm{{Cl}}}_{2} \) ) and extract with aqueous acid \( \left( {\mathrm{{pH}} < 4}\right) \) ; this will remove the pyridine as an aqueous solution of its protonated form. Then extract the remaining organic layer with aqueous base \( \left( {\mathrm{{pH}} > 6}\right) \) which will extract the \( p \) -toluic acid as its anion. You now have three solutions. Evaporate the organic solution of naphthalene and recrystallize it to get pure naphthalene. Acidify the basic solution of \( p \) -toluic acid to precipitate the free acid and recrystallize it. Finally,add base to the pyridine solution,extract the pyridine with an organic solvent,(say ether, \( {\mathrm{{Et}}}_{2}\mathrm{O} \) ,or \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2}{\mathrm{{Cl}}}_{2} \) ),evaporate the solvent,and distil the pyridine. It is just as good to extract with base first and acid second.

## Problem 2

In the separation of benzoic acid from toluene we suggested using \( \mathrm{{NaOH}} \) solution. How concentrated a solution would be necessary to ensure that the \( \mathrm{{pH}} \) was above the \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) of benzoic acid \( \left( {p{K}_{a}}\right. \) 4.2)? How would you estimate how much solution to use?

## Purpose of the problem

You can check your understanding of the relationship between \( \mathrm{{pH}} \) and concentration.

## Suggested solution

Even a very weak solution of \( \mathrm{{NaOH}} \) will have a \( \mathrm{{pH}} > {4.2} \) . By the calculation on p. 184 of the chapter, for a \( \mathrm{{pH}} \) of 5 we should need \( \left\lbrack  {{\mathrm{H}}_{3}{\mathrm{O}}^{ + }}\right\rbrack   = {10}^{-5}\mathrm{\;{mol}}{\mathrm{{dm}}}^{-1} \) . We know that the ionic product of water is \( \left\lbrack  {{\mathrm{H}}_{3}{\mathrm{O}}^{ + }}\right\rbrack  \left\lbrack  {\mathrm{{OH}}}^{ - }\right\rbrack   = {10}^{-{14}} \) and so for \( \mathrm{{pH}}5 \) we need \( {10}^{-5}\mathrm{\;{mol}}{\mathrm{{dm}}}^{-1} \) of \( \mathrm{{NaOH}} \) . This is very dilute! The trouble is that you need one hydroxide ion for every molecule of benzoic acid so if you had, say, \( {1.22}\mathrm{\;g}{\mathrm{{PhCO}}}_{2}\mathrm{H}\left( { = {0.01}\text{equiv.}}\right) \) you would need 1000 litres \( \left( {\mathrm{{dm}}}^{-1}\right) \) of your \( \mathrm{{NaOH}} \) solution. It makes more sense to have a much more concentrated solution, say, 0.1M. This would give an unnecessarily high \( \mathrm{{pH}} \) of 13 but you would need only \( {100}\mathrm{{ml}}\left( {\mathrm{{cm}}}^{3}\right) \) to extract your benzoic acid.

What species would be present if you were to dissolve this hydroxy-acid in: (a) water at \( \mathrm{{pH}}7 \) ;

(b) aqueous alkali at \( \mathrm{{pH}}{12} \) ; or (c) a concentrated solution of a mineral acid?

## Purpose of the problem

Revision of simple acidity and basicity requiring \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) values in a practical situation.

## Suggested solution

The \( {\mathrm{{CO}}}_{2}\mathrm{H} \) group will have a \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) of about 4-5 and the \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) group a \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) of about 10 . This gives a comfortable margin between the two ionizations. At \( \mathrm{{pH}}7 \) the acid will be ionized and at \( \mathrm{{pH}}{12} \) both groups will be ionized. In concentrated mineral acid both will have their protons and the carboxylic acid will start to be protonated. It is more readily protonated than the isolated \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) group as it gives a delocalized cation.

## Suggested solution

Both compounds are quite polar and not very soluble in the usual organic NMR solvents. In addition, they have \( \mathrm{{NH}} \) or \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) protons that exchange and broaden the signals. If the exchange is made rapid by acid or base catalysis and the NHs and OHs exchanged for deuterium, all these problems disappear and clean sharp spectra result. The first compound is a guanidine and forms a cation in acid. The cation is symmetrical and a very simple spectrum results - just three types of carbon in the aromatic region and one very low field carbon (at large \( \delta \) ) for the carbon in the middle of the cation.

## Purpose of the problem

To get you thinking about carbon acids, how their anions are delocalized, and what makes the anions stable.

## Suggested solution

All these carbon acids give anions whose negative charge is mainly on oxygen. Similar ones are described in the chapter (Table 8.2,p. 193) and we expect simple carbonyl compounds to have \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}}\mathrm{s} \) of about 15- 20 and 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds to have \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}}\mathrm{s} \) of about 5-15. The first three compounds are all ketones on the left and have ketone, aldehyde, and ester groups on the right, respectively. The charge is delocalized over both carbonyl groups. The aldehyde is most effective as it is a simple carbonyl group. The ketone has \( \sigma \) -conjugation,which reduces the effectiveness of the carbonyl delocalization,and the ester is worst as it has competing conjugation from the ester oxygen atom.

What does not happen is Grignard formation at the aryl chloride - bromides are more reactive than chlorides towards Grignard formation. This is because \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{N} \) is less electrophilic than \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) ( \( \mathrm{N} \) is less electronegative than \( \mathrm{O} \) ) and also because attack at \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{N} \) would destroy the aromaticity of the pyridine ring.

<!-- Media -->

## Purpose of the problem

Extension of simple ideas to more exotic reagents with trapping of the intermediate.

## Suggested solution

The phosphine is a soft reversible nucleophile and is good at conjugate addition while unsaturated ketones are good at both types of reaction. On balance, conjugate addition wins. The intermediate enolate is trapped by silicon - an excellent electrophile for oxygen. The product is indeed a cation. The nucleophile was neutral and has lost electrons in the addition step. The counterion is chloride as all the atoms in the reagents are incorporated into the product.

<!-- Media -->

<table><tr><td>Compound</td><td>\( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}} \) ,p.p.m.</td><td>pKa</td></tr><tr><td>CH3NO2</td><td>4.33</td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>\( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2}{\left( {\mathrm{{NO}}}_{2}\right) }_{2} \)</td><td>6.10</td><td>4</td></tr><tr><td>\( \mathrm{{CH}}{\left( {\mathrm{{NO}}}_{2}\right) }_{3} \)</td><td>7.52</td><td>0</td></tr></table>

<!-- Media -->

## Purpose of the problem

Simple correlation of structure and chemical shift.

## Suggested solution

The nitro group is a strongly electron-withdrawing group and would be expected to remove electron shielding from neighbouring hydrogen atoms. A \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{3} \) group would normally come at about 1.2 p.p.m. so one nitro group has shifted this downfield by about 3 p.p.m. The second adds less than 2 p.p.m. and the third only just 1.4 p.p.m. These diminishing effects are much smaller than the effects on \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) ,which is a log scale, but in the same direction. There is a kind of correlation showing that removing electrons from a \( \mathrm{C} - \mathrm{H} \) bond makes it more acidic and also increases the chemical shift.

## Problem 8

A nitration product \( \left( {{\mathrm{C}}_{8}{\mathrm{H}}_{11}{\mathrm{\;N}}_{3}{\mathrm{O}}_{2}}\right) \) of this pyridine has been isolated which has a nitro \( \left( {\mathrm{{NO}}}_{2}\right) \) group somewhere on the molecule. From the \( {90}\mathrm{{MHz}}{}^{1}\mathrm{H} \) NMR spectrum,deduce whether the nitro group is (a) on the ring, (b) on the NH nitrogen atom, or (c) on the aliphatic side chain and then exactly where it is. Give a full analysis of the spectrum.

## Purpose of the problem

Practice at interpretation of high-field NMR spectra. More complex problems can be solved reasonably easily.

## Suggested solution

The three types of compound under consideration are these (there are isomers of the first and last).

<!-- Media -->

`CCCN(C1=NC=CC=C1)N(Cl)Cl.CC(CNC1=NC=CC=C1)N(Cl)Cl.CCCNC1=NC(=CC=C1)[N+](=O)[O-]`

<!-- Media -->

Checking the integral will deal with that problem. The propyl side chain is still there with a \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{3} \) triplet,a \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2} \) quintet,and a \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2} \) triplet with a large chemical shift. The broad signal at \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}}{5.9} \) p.p.m. is typical of an NH group so no reaction has happened there. The small signal - less than a quarter of a proton - at 7.2 p.p.m. cannot be part of the molecule and must be \( {\mathrm{{CHCl}}}_{3} \) . The remaining signals in the aromatic region at 6.3,8.1,and 9.1 p.p.m. must be three protons on the pyridine ring. The nitro group has replaced one of the original four and is somewhere on the pyridine ring. These are the possibilities.

<!-- Media -->

`CCCNC1=NC=CC(=C1)N.CCCNC1=NC=CC=C1N.CCCNC1=NC=CC=C1.CCCNC1=NC=CC=C1`

<!-- Media -->

The most significant feature of the aromatic region is a proton at very large chemical shift (9.1 p.p.m.) with no coupling to speak of (there might be some long-range coupling). This proton has no neighbours and that rules out the 3-nitro and 6-nitro compounds. If you check in tables you will see that protons on carbons next to nitrogen (C2 and C6) in pyridine have very large shifts as you would expect from their aldehyde-like nature. The nitro group also increases the shifts of protons on neighbouring carbon atoms. The compound must be 5-nitro and the spectrum can be assigned like this.

The coupling in the side chain is all about \( 7\mathrm{\;{Hz}} \) as expected and that between \( \mathrm{C}3 \) and \( \mathrm{C}4 \) in the pyridine ring is somewhat larger also as expected for an aromatic ring. The smaller chemical shift of the proton at \( \mathrm{C}3 \) occurs because it is not affected by the nitro group but it is affected by electron donation from the amine nitrogen atom.

The natural product bullatenone was isolated in the 1950s from a New Zealand myrtle and assigned the structure 9A. Then compound 9A was synthesized and found not to be identical with natural bullatenone. Predict the expected \( {}^{1}\mathrm{H} \) NMR spectrum of 9A. Given the full spectroscopic data available nowadays, but not in the 1950s, say why 9A is definitely wrong and suggest a better structure for builatenone.

## Spectra of bullatenone:

Mass spectrum: \( \mathrm{m}/\mathrm{z}{188}\left( {{10}\% }\right) \) (high resolution confirms \( {\mathrm{C}}_{12}{\mathrm{H}}_{12}{\mathrm{O}}_{2} \) ), 105 (20%), 102 (100%), and 77 (20%).

Infrared: 1604 and \( {1705}{\mathrm{\;{cm}}}^{-1} \) .

\( {}^{1}\mathrm{H} \) NMR: \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}} \) (p.p.m.) 1.45 \( \left( {6\mathrm{H},\mathrm{s}}\right) ,{5.82}\left( {1\mathrm{H},\mathrm{s}}\right) ,{7.35}\left( {3\mathrm{H},\mathrm{m}}\right) \) ,and 7.68(2H,m).

## Purpose of the problem

Detecting wrong structures is fun and teaches us to be alert to what the spectra are telling us rather than what we expect.

## Suggested solution

The mass spectrum and infrared are all right for structure 9A but the NMR shows at once that bullatenone cannot be \( 9\mathrm{\;A} \) . There is indeed a monosubstituted benzene ring (the \( 2\mathrm{H} \) and \( 3\mathrm{H} \) signals in the aromatic region confirm this) but the aliphatic protons consist of a \( 6\mathrm{H} \) signal,almost certainly a \( {\mathrm{{CMe}}}_{2} \) group,and a \( 1\mathrm{H} \) singlet in the alkene region at 5.82 p.p.m.

The fragments we have are \( \mathrm{{Ph}} \) ,carbonyl,and \( {\mathrm{{CMe}}}_{2} \) groups and an alkene with one \( \mathrm{H} \) on it. That adds up to \( {\mathrm{C}}_{12}{\mathrm{H}}_{12}\mathrm{O} \) and leaves only one oxygen atom to fit in. There must still be a ring or else there will be too few hydrogen atoms and the ring is five-membered (just try other possibilities yourself). There are three basic rings we can choose and each can have the phenyl group on either end of the double bond making six possibilities in all.

<!-- Media -->

`CC1(C)C(=CC(=O)N1[O-])[Hg].CC1(C)C(=CC(=O)N1[O-])[Hg].CC1(C)C(=CC(=O)N1[O-])[Hg].CC1(C)C(=CC(=O)N1[O-])[Hg].CC1(C)C=C([N+](=O)N1[O-])[Hg].CC1(C)C=C([N+](=O)N1[O-])[Hg].[Hg].[Hg]`

<!-- Media -->

The last four are all esters (cyclic esters or lactones) and they would have IR carbonyl stretches at higher frequency in the \( {1745} - {1780}{\mathrm{\;{cm}}}^{-1} \) range. The hydrogen on the alkene cannot be on the same carbon atom as the oxygen or it would be at a very large shift indeed whereas it is close to the 'normal' alkene shift of 5.25 p.p.m. For 9C we could estimate 5.25 + 0.64 p.p.m. for O, + 0.36 p.p.m. for Ph, and \( + {0.87}\mathrm{p} \) .p.m. for \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) making 7.12 p.p.m.,a long way from the observed 5.82 p.p.m. Structure 9B is correct and the spectra can be assigned.

Compound \( 9\mathrm{\;B} \) was synthesized and proved identical to natural bullatenone.

## Problem 12

Precocene is a compound that causes insect larvae to pupate and can also be found in some plants (Ageratum spp.) where it may act as an insecticide. It was isolated in minute amounts and has the following spectroscopic details. Propose a structure for precocene. Spectra of precocene:

Mass spectrum: \( \mathrm{m}/\mathrm{z} \) (high resolution gives \( {\mathrm{C}}_{13}{\mathrm{H}}_{16}{\mathrm{O}}_{3} \) ), \( \mathrm{M} - {15}\left( {{100}\% }\right) \) and \( \mathrm{M} - {30} \) (weak)

## Purpose of the problem

Your first attempt at determining the structure of a natural product without any hints - not even a wrong structure.

## Suggested solution

The mass spectrum gives us the formula \( \left( {{\mathrm{C}}_{13}{\mathrm{H}}_{16}{\mathrm{O}}_{3}}\right) \) ,which looks like an aromatic compound as there are so few hydrogens,and the base peak at \( \mathrm{M} - {15} \) suggests that a methyl group is lost rather easily. 1.34 (6H,s): two identical methyl groups,probably \( {\mathrm{{CMe}}}_{2} \) . Rather large shift.

3.80 (3H, s) and 3.82 (3H, s): two different OMe groups.

\( {5.54}\left( {1\mathrm{H},\mathrm{d},{J10}\mathrm{\;{Hz}}}\right) \) and \( {6.37}\left( {1\mathrm{H},\mathrm{d},{J10}\mathrm{\;{Hz}}}\right) \) : two \( c \) is protons on an alkene.

\( {6.42}\left( {1\mathrm{H},\mathrm{s}}\right) \) and \( {6.58}\left( {1\mathrm{H},\mathrm{s}}\right) \) : two isolated protons on an aromatic ring,probably 1,4-related as there is no coupling. Rather small shifts - electron-rich ring.

If all this is true, we have these fragments.

Why does this work?

## Purpose of the problem

This question may sound trivial but students starting organic chemistry often make the error of trying to form esters from carboxylic acids in basic solution. Thinking about the reasons may save you from the error.

## Suggested solution

The reaction works in acid solution because the carboxylic acid gets protonated and becomes a good electrophile. Later, the intermediate gets protonated again so that a molecule of water can be lost.

## Suggested solution

The answer to the first question is that the difference in \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) values is very great (11.6 - remember that this means a factor of \( {10}^{11.6} \) as it is a \( \log \) scale) and there is enough acid to protonate all the amine. The equilibrium constant is enormous.

In the second step,acetate ion \( \left( {\mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{{aH}}}}\right. \) about 5 ) and \( \mathrm{{HCl}}\left( {\mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} - 7}\right) \) set up an equilibrium with acetic acid and chloride ion. The difference in \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) values is still great and that equilibrium too will be right over on one side. However,the main point is that the \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) values of acetic acid and \( {\mathrm{{PhNH}}}_{3}^{ + } \) are about the same so there will be about the same amount of each - the equilibrium constant will be about 1. Most of the amine will still be in solution as the cation but there will be enough free amine to react. If no sodium acetate were added, the amine would all be in solution as the cation and there would be essentially no free amine to act as a nucleophile. It would be simpler but no reaction: would occur.

<!-- Media -->

`CC(C)(CC(=O)O)CO.CC1(CC#CC#C[C@@H]2CCCC2=O)CC(=O)OC1.C1C[C@@H](C#CC#CC#CC2CCCC2(O)O)C(=O)C1`

<!-- Media -->

## Purpose of the problem

Practice at assessing the likely effect of acid and base on particular examples of equilibria.

## Suggested solution

The first example is an esterification (or lactonization as the product is a cyclic ester or lactone \( \rightarrow \) the forwards direction and an ester hydrolysis in the backwards direction. Ester hydrolysis 23 catalysed by acid or base but esterification by acid only. In addition, even a weak base will be enough to turn the starting material into the carboxylate anion, which will not cyclize. The equilibrium is to the right in acid solution and to the left in basic solution.

The second example is the familiar one of cyanohydrin formation from a ketone. The reaction is indeed reversible but in basic solution the cyanide anion is more stable than the oxyanion in the product and the carbonyl group is very stable too. In acidic solution (at pHs less than about 12) the oxyanion will be protonated and the reaction driven over to the right.

## Problem 11

Elemental sulfur normally exists as an eight membered ring \( \left( {\mathrm{S}}_{8}\right) \) ,but it can also be found in a number of other states. How would entropy and enthalpy affect the equilibrium between sulfur in these two forms? Purpose of the problem

<!-- Media -->

`C#CC.C1SSSSSSS1.S1SSS1`

<!-- Media -->

Practice at assessing the likely effect of entropy on equilibria.

## Suggested solution

The equilibrium position is determined both by enthalpy and entropy as discussed on p. 312 of the shapter. Entropy favours the larger number of molecules as they have greater randomness so heat will drive the equilibrium to the right. Enthalpy will favour the eight-membered ring as it has no ring strain and so lower temperatures favour the left-hand side.

## Purpose of the problem

The other important kind of structure determination: compounds isolated from a chemice reaction.

## Suggested solution

Compound \( 7\mathrm{\;A} \) is much the simpler so we start with that. The two reagents are \( {\mathrm{C}}_{5}{\mathrm{H}}_{6}{\mathrm{O}}_{4} \) and \( {\mathrm{C}}_{5}{\mathrm{H}}_{8}{\mathrm{O}}_{2} \) which adds up to \( {\mathrm{C}}_{10}{\mathrm{H}}_{14}{\mathrm{O}}_{6} \) or 230 so 60 has been lost. That looks like \( {\mathrm{C}}_{2}{\mathrm{H}}_{4}{\mathrm{O}}_{2} \) or less likely \( {\mathrm{C}}_{3}{\mathrm{H}}_{8}\mathrm{O} \) (because it is saturated). If the first is right, \( 7\mathrm{\;A} \) is \( {\mathrm{C}}_{8}{\mathrm{H}}_{10}{\mathrm{O}}_{4} \) which at least fits the proton NMR.

The IR suggests two carbonyl groups,though the \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) NMR suggests one only,but the molecule must have some symmetry as there are only five signals for eight carbon atoms. The proton NMS shows a \( {\mathrm{{CMe}}}_{2} \) group and four identical protons,which can only be two identical \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2} \) groups. The only unsaturation is the two carbonyl groups so the \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) signal at 105 p.p.m. is very strange. It,like-the signal at 22 p.p.m., is probably a quaternary carbon as it is weak and it must be next to two oxygen atoms to have such a large shift. Either 22 or 105 p.p.m. must be C of \( {\mathrm{{CMe}}}_{2} \) . The last two: degrees of unsaturation must be rings. The cyclopropane would supply one ring and the two links: and symmetrical \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2} \) groups and the carbon at 22 p.p.m. would be the atom joining that ring to the two carbonyl groups leaving 105 p.p.m. to be \( \mathrm{C} \) of \( {\mathrm{{CMe}}}_{2} \) . So we have:

Compound 7B has nitrogen in it (odd MW) and clearly has the benzene ring too from the NMR we can put down PhN \( \left( { = {91}}\right) \) as part of the structure. It also has two carbonyl groups (in IR,the and at \( {1670}{\mathrm{\;{cm}}}^{-1} \) looks like an amide) and they are both acid derivatives \( \left( {{}^{13}\mathrm{C}\text{NMR}}\right) \) . There are fitted aliphatic carbons,two \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2}\mathrm{\;s} \) and one \( \mathrm{{CH}} \) . Adding these together gives us \( {\mathrm{C}}_{11}{\mathrm{H}}_{10}{\mathrm{{NO}}}_{2} = {188} \) so that is 17 missing which looks like \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) . Since we need a second acid derivative and the \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) is the remaining heteroatom,it must be a carboxylic acid. Given that the \( \mathrm{{CH}} \) is a triplet,it must be text to one of the \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2}\mathrm{\;s} \) and,as they are both multiplets,they must be joined to each other. There is the more degree of unsaturation so there is a ring. So we have:

<!-- Media -->

To assemble three fragments into a molecule we must plug the amide into the \( {\mathrm{C}}_{3} \) fragment to the a ring and put the \( {\mathrm{{CO}}}_{2}\mathrm{H} \) group on the last free position. We can do this in two ways. Proton NMR distinguishes these. The end \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2} \) is attached either to the nitrogen atom minated 3.2 p.p.m.) or to the carbonyl group (estimated 2.2 p.p.m.) of the amide. The derived value of 3.92 p.p.m. fits the first better. A similar estimate for the \( \mathrm{{CH}} \) also suggests the structure. This is indeed the correct answer.

## Purpose of the problem

Structure determination of reaction products by proton NMR alone with extra twists - an element with spin (P) and protons on the same carbon atom that are different in the NMR.

## Suggested solution

The coupling constants \( \left( {{}^{3}{J}_{\mathrm{{PH}}}}\right) \) across the double bond in \( {12}\mathrm{\;A} \) are very large. Typically \( {cis}{}^{3}{J}_{\mathrm{{PH}}} \) is about \( {20}\mathrm{\;{Hz}} \) and trans \( {}^{3}{J}_{\mathrm{{PH}}} \) is about \( {40}\mathrm{\;{Hz}} \) . Geminal \( \left( {{}^{2}{J}_{\mathrm{{PH}}}}\right) \) coupling constants are also large but more variable. In 12B there is a stereogenic centre so that the hydrogen atoms and methyl groups i.e. the ring are either on the same side as \( \mathrm{{MeO}} \) or the same side as \( \mathrm{{Ph}} \) . They are diastereotopic with different chemical shifts and the Hs couple \( \left( {{}^{2}J}\right) \) . We cannot say which is which.

## Purpose of the problem

Nomenclature may be the least important of the organic chemists’ necessary skills,but giving \( R \) or \( S \) designation to simple compounds does matter. These three check your basic knowledge of the rules

## Purpose of the problem

How to choose between the \( {\mathrm{S}}_{\mathrm{N}}1 \) or \( {\mathrm{S}}_{\mathrm{N}}2 \) mechanism when the choice is more subtle.

## Suggested solution

Carbonate is a strong enough base to remove protons from phenols \( \left( {\mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}}}\right. \) about 10 ) but not from alcohols. One oxyanion will be formed at a time and will displace a bromide ion in an \( {\mathrm{S}}_{\mathrm{N}}2 \) reaction. It doesn’t matter which goes first. Both react by the \( {\mathrm{S}}_{\mathrm{N}}2 \) mechanism because one is primary and the other, though secondary, is next to a carbonyl group and the cation would be very unstable while the \( {\mathrm{S}}_{\mathrm{N}}2 \) mechanism is excellent.

## Problem 4

By working at low temperature with one equivalent of a buffered solution of a peroxy-acid, it is possible to prepare the monoepoxide of cyclopentadiene. Why are the precautions necessary and why does the epoxidation not occur again?

<!-- Media -->

`C1=CC2C(C1)O2.C1=CCC=C1.[Na].O[R10b](=O)O.O[R10](=O)O`

<!-- Media -->

## Purpose of the problem

A more complicated electrophilic addition with questions of stability and selectivity added.

## Suggested solution

One of the double bonds in the diene reacts in the usual way first of all to give the monoepoxide. Two questions then arise. If the reaction can be made to stop there, the monoalkene must be less nucleophilic than the diene. This is so because the HOMO reacts. The HOMO of an alkene is just the populated \( \pi \) orbital. The HOMO of a diene is \( {\Psi }^{2} \) resulting from the antibonding addition of the two separate \( \pi \) orbitals and is less stable than either \( \pi \) orbital.

<!-- Media -->

<!-- figureText: HOMO of the diene danger of allyl cation -->

`C1=CC2CC1C3C4CC(C(C4)O)C23.C1=CC2CC1C3C4CC(C(C4)O)C23.C1=CC2CC1C3C4CC(C(C4)O)C23.C1=CC2CC1C3C4CC(C(C4)O)C23.COP(=O)(O)OC.COP(=O)(O)OC`

<!-- Media -->

The other question is why work at low temperature and buffer the solution? The low temperature favours the kinetic product and discourages the slower second epoxidation. A by-product from epoxidation is the acid \( {\mathrm{{RCO}}}_{2}\mathrm{H} \) and there is a danger that this may catalyse opening of the monoepoxide to give the allyl cation in the frame. A buffer prevents the solution from becoming too acidic.

## Purpose of the problem

Revision of conformational analysis from Chapter 18 and a mechanism for a new electrophile.

## Suggested solution

The anion \( {\mathrm{{ClO}}}^{ - } \) cannot be an electrophile: one protonation makes it neutral \( \mathrm{{HOCl}} \) but it becomes electrophilic enough to attack an alkene only after a second protonation. Attack of the chlorine enc of \( {\mathrm{{ClOH}}}_{2}^{ + } \) evidently occurs from underneath the alkene,presumably because the two substituents (Me and AcO) are on the top surface. Attack by water must then be from the opposite (top) face but why does it occur at the less substituted carbon? This is a conformational question: we must get the trans diaxial product for the correct alignment of orbitals (Chapter 18).

Acid anhydrides,being carbonyl electrophiles with polarized \( \mathrm{C} = \mathrm{O} \) bonds,respond to charge density (they are 'hard' electrophiles) and react well with oxygen nucleophiles. Bromine, by contrast, is uncharged and unpolarized (it is a 'soft' electrophile) and reacts well with neutral nucleophiles such as alkenes (Chapter 20). Each electrophile reacts regioselectively with the part of the enol that suits it best.

## Purpose of the problem

A more quantitative assessment of the relative reactivities of the various positions in an aromatic \( = \mathrm{g} \) .

## suggested solution

There are two ortho and two meta sites but only one para site so the ratio would be \( 2 : 2 : 1 \) o:m:p if were equally reactive. It is actually 30:2:37 or 15:1:18 or 43:3:54 depending on how you recessed it. The ortho and para positions are roughly equally reactive because the alkyl group is electron-donating. We have now answered the question but you might like to go a stage further. Both A and C are formed with alkylation of benzene as the first step. The decomposition of the acylium ion is evidently faster than the acylation of benzene. However, when B reacts further, it is mainly acylated (only a small amount of di- \( t \) -butyl benzene is formed). Evidently,the decomposition of the acylium ion is slower than the acylation of \( \mathrm{B} \) ! This is not,in fact,unreasonable as the \( t \) -Bu group in B accelerates electrophilic attack - it is just a dramatic demonstration of that acceleration.

## Purpose of the problem

- lightly artificial exercise in matching conditions to deprotection.

## Suggested solution

Step 1: Fluoride attacks silicon and releases the OH group on C4. Step 2: Mild acidic conditions 7. inclyse the only acetal, a THP derivative at C5. Step 3: Zinc is a two-electron donor that attacks halogens and releases the \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) on \( \mathrm{C}2 \) by an elimination reaction. Step 4: These are the one-conditions and are ideal for ester hydrolysis,releasing the \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) on \( \mathrm{C}1 \) . Step 5: The only prote-group susceptible to hydrogenolysis is the benzyl ether at C3. Step 6: The most robust group are most difficult to cleave is the methyl ether at C6. Several other orders of events are possible step 6 is very vigorous and would cleave the acetal at C5 for example.

## Purpose of the problem

NMR revision in the context of conjugate addition.

## Suggested solution

The IR suggests a dicarbonyl compound and the \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) NMR suggests one aldehyde or ketone (200) and one acid derivative (178). The proton NMR confirms an aldehyde (10.1) and suggests that acid derivative is a methyl ester (3H singlet at \( {\delta 4.3} \) ). Both NMRs show that there is no double be any more. The proton NMR reveals a \( {\mathrm{{CMe}}}_{2} \) group on saturated carbon with no adjacent hydrog. ( \( 6\mathrm{H} \) singlet at \( {\delta 1.21} \) ). There are two \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2} \) groups coupled to each other but to nothing else (the - triplets). All this adds up to this aldehyde-ester.

Rehearsal of the mechanism of a conjugate addition with an extended enolate.

The enone could form an enolate on the methyl group (kinetic) or a more stable extended enolate removal of a proton from the far end \( \left( \gamma \right) \) of the molecule. Evidently,this is what happens here and extended enolate attacks at the first carbon along the chain \( \left( \alpha \right) \) to add one cyanoethyl group. Repetic adds the second cyanoethyl group and blocks the \( \alpha \) position against any further enolate formation

## Purpose of the problem

Practice in analysing a mechanism where stereochemistry gives a clue.

## Suggested solution

The reaction is highly stereoselective but the minor products suggest that a simple dropping out of \( {\mathrm{{CO}}}_{2} \) from the lactone is not the answer. An E1 reaction with a zwitterionic intermediate formed by opening the lactone gives a way to all the products. The clue is that,at the moment \( {\mathrm{{CO}}}_{2} \) is lost,the bond linking it to the rest of the molecule must be parallel to the empty p orbital of the cation.

Exploration of the usefulness of the NOE when coupling constants are of little use.

\( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}}{2.22}\left( {1\mathrm{H},\mathrm{d},{J4}}\right) ,{2.99}\left( {1\mathrm{H},\mathrm{{dd}},{J4},{2.4}}\right) ,{4.36}\left( {1\mathrm{H},\mathrm{d},{J12.3}}\right) ,{4.70}\left( {1\mathrm{H},\mathrm{{dd}},{J4.7},{11.7}}\right) . \) 4.88 (1H, d, J 12.3)

## Purpose of the problem

assigning stereochemistry when there are isolated spin systems.

## Suggested solution

The signals given are all of protons next to electronegative atoms. There are two AB systems for the destereotopic \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2} \) groups in the epoxide and the \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2}\mathrm{{OAc}} \) group. The \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2}\mathrm{{OAc}} \) group is ’normal’ with \( {}^{2}{J12.3} \) and a large shift ( \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}}{4.36} \) and 4.88). The epoxide is unusual with a much smaller \( {}^{2}J \) of Jy 4 Hz (actually normal for epoxides) and smaller shifts ( \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}} \) 2.22 and 2.99). Both appear isolated the optimic optihe epoxide protons shows long-range coupling to some other proton. These are no help with the stereochemistry but the proton next to the other OAc group \( \left( {{\delta }_{\mathrm{H}}{4.70}}\right) \) is clearly axial with -pical axial/axial (11.7) and axial/equatorial (4.7) couplings.

The answer came from NOE experiments There were large NOEs between the \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}}{4.70} \) axial proton and one of the epoxide protons and between the axial methyl group and one of the protons in the \( {\mathrm{{CH}}}_{2}\mathrm{{OAc}} \) group. The stereochemistry is like this.

## Problem 13

The seeds of the Costa Rican plant Ateleia herbert smithii are avoided by all seed eaters (except a weevil that adapts them for its defence) because they contain two toxic amino acids (IR spectra like other amino acids). Neither compound is chiral. What is the structure of these compounds? They can easily be separated because one (A) is soluble in aqueous base but the other (B) is not.

\( \mathrm{A} \) is \( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}{\mathrm{H}}_{9}{\mathrm{{NO}}}_{4} \) (mass spectrum) and has \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{C}}{34.0}\left( \mathrm{d}\right) ,{40.0}\left( \mathrm{t}\right) ,{56.2}\left( \mathrm{s}\right) ,{184.8}\left( \mathrm{s}\right) \) ,and 186.0 (s). Its proton NMR has three exchanging protons on nitrogen and one on oxygen and two complex signals at \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}}{2.68}\left( {4\mathrm{H},{\mathrm{A}}_{2}{\mathrm{\;B}}_{2}}\right. \) part of \( {\mathrm{A}}_{2}{\mathrm{\;B}}_{2}\mathrm{X} \) system) and 3.37 ( \( \mathrm{X} \) part of \( {\mathrm{A}}_{2}{\mathrm{\;B}}_{2}\mathrm{X} \) system) with \( {J}_{\mathrm{{AB}}}{9.5},{J}_{\mathrm{{AX}}}{9.1} \) ,and \( {J}_{\mathrm{{BX}}} \) small.

B is \( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}{\mathrm{H}}_{9}{\mathrm{{NO}}}_{2} \) (mass spectrum) and has \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{C}}{38.0}\left( \mathrm{d}\right) ,{41.3}\left( \mathrm{t}\right) ,{50.4}\left( \mathrm{t}\right) ,{75.2}\left( \mathrm{s}\right) \) ,and 173.0 (s). Its proton NMR spectrum contains two exchanging protons on nitrogen and \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}}{1.17}(2\mathrm{H} \) , ddd, J 2.3, 6.2, 9.5), 2.31 (2H, broad m), 2.90 (1H, broad t, J 3.2), and 3.40 (2H, broad s).

Because the coupling pattern did not show up clearly as many of the coupling constants are small,decoupling experiments were used. Irradiation at \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}}{3.4} \) simplifies the \( {\delta }_{\mathrm{H}}{2.3} \) signal to(2H,ddd,J5.8,3.2,2.3),sharpens each line of the ddd at 1.17,and sharpens the triplet at 2.9 .

Irradiation at 2.9 sharpens the signals at 1.17 and 2.9 and makes the signal at 2.31 into a broad doublet, \( J \) about 6 . Irradiation at 2.31 sharpens the signal at 3.4 slightly and reduces the signals at 2.9 and 1.17 to broad singlets. Irradiation at 1.17 sharpens the signal at 3.4 slightly so that it is a broad doublet, \( J \) about 1.0,sharpens the signal at 2.9 to a triplet,and sharpens up the signal at 2.31 but irradiation here had the least effect.

This is quite a difficult problem but the compounds are so small \( \left( {\mathrm{C}}_{6}\right. \) only),have no methyl groups, and have some symmetry so you should try drawing structures at an early stage.

## Purpose of the problem

A gentle introduction to stereochemical control in rings.

## Suggested solution

The reducing agent could attack either side of the ring in the first step but it reacts with the free \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) group to produce a new reducing agent and hydride delivery is intramolecular from the bottom face. The mesylation (mechanism on p. 484) does not affect the stereochemistry as no bonds are formed or broken to any of the chiral centres.

## Purpose of the problem

Another cyclization reaction and an example of a controlled inversion of configuration.

## Suggested solution

The first stereoselective reaction is surprising as it may appear that the initial alkylation decides stereochemistry. But that is not the case as you will see if you draw the mechanism. The estimation enolate is very easily formed as it is stabilized by the pyridine ring and the nitrile as well as by the ester. Even a weakish base like carbonate is good enough.

Proble

The first intermediate produced by alkylation with the primary alkyl bromide (or the epoxide) has two chiral centres and will no doubt be formed as a mixture of diastereoisomers. But this doesn't matter as the enolate has to be reformed for the next alkylation and that destroys one of the chiral centres. We are back to a single compound again.

All depends on the arrangement of the molecule for the cyclization step. The mechanism is straightforward enough but drawing the transition state is tricky. We offer two drawings: an attempt at a conformational drawing and a Newman projection. The vital feature in both is that the enolate carbon,and the \( \mathrm{C} - \mathrm{O} \) bond of the epoxide must be collinear. The molecule folds so that the end of the five-membered ring bends upwards away from the large pyridine ring. You may have a better drawing. This is not obvious even when you know the answer.

## Purpose of the problem

A reminder that cyclic molecules may stop some reactions as well as helping to control others.

## Suggested solution

Formation of the lithium enolate leads to elimination in the first example. If we rotate the central bond of the starting material we see that this would be a cis elimination so it must be E1cB and not E2. The stereochemistry of the product is determined stereoselectively by the best arrangement in the transition state for the elimination step.

## Suggested solution

The bicarbonate \( \left( {\mathrm{{NaHCO}}}_{3}\right) \) is a strong enough base to produce the anion of the carboxylic acid. ## Suggested solution

The dienes are the same, the ring sizes are the same, and the only difference is the presence of the benzene ring in the faster reacting compound. We should draw a mechanism for one of the reactions just to see what is happening.

<!-- Media -->

We are making two new rings. The six-membered ring containing a cis-alkene presents no problem. The eight-membered ring with a ketone in it might present a problem, and the ten-membered ring with the trans-alkene is definitely a problem. It is much easier to make medium (8- to 14-membered) rings when there is a cis-alkene elsewhere in the ring and the benzene ring helps there. It increases the population of conformations with the ends of their chains close together. It probably also lowers the energy of the LUMO.

A gentle introduction to an electrocyclic reaction without stereo- or regioselectivity.

Grignard reagents generally prefer direct to conjugate addition especially with unsaturate aldehydes. \( {\mathrm{{MnO}}}_{2} \) specializes in oxidizing allylic alcohols and is the gentle oxidizing agent we need to produce the unstable dienone.

## Purpose of the problem

Exploring the 'semipinacol' rearrangement with some revision of stereochemistry and acetal formation.

## Suggested solution

The formation of the acetal is by the usual mechanism (p. 342) with one twist. The double bond is in conjugation with the ketone in the starting material but has moved in the acetal. There is no longer any conjugation possible but how and why does it move? How is easy. At several stages in the acetal mechanism, intermediates are formed that can enolize - we show one possibility. The conjugated and the unconjugated intermediate are in equilibrium and either can cyclize to the acetal. So the 'unconjugated' acetal must be more stable. This is partly because one of the C-Q bonds must be axial and it is better for the acetal centre to be on a true chair than on a twist-chair conformation.

## Purpose of the problem

Helping you to recognize the Favorskii reaction (p. 990).

## suggested solution

The most acidic proton in the molecule is the \( \mathrm{{NH}} \) of the amide. Loss of the chloride ion from the Stilling anion gives a sort of oxyallyl cation and this can close in a disrotatory electrocyclic two-accretion process. The resulting cation is just a strange way of drawing a three-membered cyclic and attack of hydroxide on this strained molecule releases the best anion (nitrogen) and gives the product. We know that the \( {\mathrm{{CO}}}_{2}\mathrm{H} \) group in the product is down and so the conrotation must scar with the hydrogen (and the lone pair on nitrogen) rotating up. This puts the new three-the rethered ring on the outside (exo- or convex face) of the folded ring system.

## Purpose of the problem

A rather simpler exercise in fragmentation also used to form a medium-sized (11-membered) ring.

## Suggested solution

The strong base removes the proton from the \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) group and the oxyanion attacks one of the carbonyl groups (they are the same). This intermediate can decompose by the loss of the oxygen that has just come in but it can alternatively lose the enolate of the other ketone. The product is then an ester with its extra conjugation and protonation of the enolate completes the reaction. The eleven-membered ring is more stable than usual because of the benzene ring (compare the solution to Problem 3, Chapter 35) and because the ester oxygen does not suffer from interactions across the ring. ## Purpose of the problem

More revision of conjugate addition of enols (Chapter 29), another ring expansion with an enough as leaving group, and an interesting stereospecific reaction.

## Suggested solution

The stable enolate of the keto-ester does conjugate addition even to an unsaturated aldehyde. The enolates of the products are in equilibrium and the ketone enolate can do a direct addition to the aldehyde to make a new six-membered ring without much selectivity at the \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) group.

`C=C(C)CCC(=C)C.C=C(C)CCl.C=C(C)C.C.[F-].[F-].[Sb+3]`

<!-- Media -->

## Purpose of the problem

Learning how to avoid a trap in writing radical mechanisms and to show you that radical reactions can be useful.

## Suggested solution

The most likely initiation at \( {500}^{ \circ  }\mathrm{C} \) is the cleavage of the \( \mathrm{C} - \mathrm{{Cl}} \) bond to release allyl and chloride radicals. The chloride radicals then attack the alkene and abstract a proton to give an allylic radical.

<!-- Media -->

`CC(C)C1CO1.CC(C)C.CC(C)C.CC(C)C.CC(C)C.CC(C)C.CC(C)C`

The trap is to form the product by dimerizing these allylic radicals. Dimerizing of radicals is known (in the acyloin reaction, for example, p. 1032), and these radicals will sometimes dimerize but it is a rare process.

## Purpose of the problem

## Suggested solution

The peroxide is a source of \( t \) -BuO* radicals and these abstract a hydrogen atom from the methyl group of the hydrocarbon. The first spectrum is that of the cyclopropylmethyl radical. The coupling to \( {\mathrm{H}}^{\mathrm{b}} \) is small because the \( \mathrm{p} \) orbital containing the odd electron is orthogonal to the \( \mathrm{C} - {\mathrm{H}}^{\mathrm{b}} \) bond.

The diazo-compound decomposes to gaseous nitrogen and a carbene under catalysis by Cu(II). Insertion into the exposed alkene gives the three-membered ring. The randomization of the label and the racemization suggest that the carboxylate falls off the allyl cation and comes back again at either end. While they are detached, the distinction between the two ends of both cation and anion disappears as they are delocalized.

## Problem 3

The Hammett \( \rho \) value for migrating aryl groups in the acid-catalysed Beckmann rearrangement is -2.0 . What does this tell us about the rate-determining step?

<!-- Media -->

`CS(=O)(=O)/C(=N\O)/C1=CC=CC=C1.CS(=O)(=O)C(=O)NC1=CC=CC=C1.C[X].C[R].C[X].C[R]`

<!-- Media -->

## Purpose of the problem

The Hammett relationship gives an intimate picture of the Beckmann rearrangement.

## Suggested solution

The normal mechanism for the Beckmann rearrangement involves protonation at \( \mathrm{{OH}} \) and migration of the group anti to the \( \mathrm{N} - \mathrm{O} \) bond (pp. 997-9),in this case the substituted benzene ring

<!-- Media -->

`CN(C)C(=NO)C1=CC=CC=C1.CN(C)C(=NO)C1=CC=CC=C1.CN(C)C(=NO)C1=CC=CC=C1.CN(C)C(=NO)C1=CC=CC=C1.C(=[N-])=O.C(=[N-])=O.C(=[N-])=O.C(=[N-])=O.[Ru+2].[Ru+2]`

<!-- Media -->

If this mechanism is correct, we should expect the migration itself to be the slow step. The fit-step is just a proton transfer to oxygen and must be fast. The steps after the migration involve attach of water on a carbocation and proton transfers between \( \mathrm{O} \) and \( \mathrm{N} \) . These must all be fast. The migration forms and breaks a C-C bond and creates an unstable cation. But does this agree with evidence? Starting material and product in the migration step are cations so the transition state mir-be a cation too. Any contribution to cation stability made by the migrating group will be welcome we should expect electron-donating groups to migrate faster. This is what we see: a \( \rho \) value of-1 shows a modest acceleration by electron-donating groups (pp. 1093-8).

In the Beckmann rearrangement, the anti group migrates, but in other rearrangements migrating group is chosen for a very different reason: it is normally the group best able to stabilize positive charge and benzene rings can do this by \( \pi \) participation (pp. 973-5). This would be a participation mechanism.

<!-- Media -->

The Hammett \( \rho \) value of -2.0 gives very definite evidence that \( \pi \) participa tion does not occur. If It did, the closure of the unstable three-membered ring would undoubtedly be the slow step and a positive charge would be formed inside the benzene ring itself. This would give a much larger \( \rho \) Blue of something like -5.0 or more. One reason participation does not occur is that the starting material is planar and the \( \mathrm{p} \) orbitals in the benzene ring cannot point in the right direction to interact with the \( {\sigma }^{ * } \) orbital of the \( \mathrm{N} - \mathrm{O} \) bond. They are orthogonal to it.

## Purpose of the problem

Interpretation of a small Hammett \( \rho \) value.

## Suggested solution

The most obvious explanation for a small Hammett \( \rho \) value,that the aromatic ring is too far aw. from the reaction site, will not wash here as the aromatic rings are joined directly to the reaction nitrogen atoms of the carbodiimide. The reaction must surely start with the protonation of one these nitrogen atoms. This cannot be the slow step and it would in any case have a large negative \( \rho \) value. The small observed \( \rho \) value suggests that the rate-determining step must have a positive \( \rho \) value that nearly cancels out the large negative \( \rho \) value for the first step. Attack by water on the protonated carbodiimide looks right.

## Purpose of the problem

An extreme example of surprising catalysis.

## Suggested solution

At first you might ask how chloride can catalyse anything at all. It is a weak base and not a very good nucleophile for the carbonyl group. However, in polar aprotic solvents like acetonitrile (MeCN), chloride is not solvated and is both more basic and more nucleophilic. In this reaction it cannot be a nucleophilic catalyst as attack on the carbonyl group simply regenerates the starting material. It cannot be a specific base as it is too weak, even in MeCN, to deprotonate methanol. But it can act as a general base. Notice how we have arrived at general species catalysis as a last resort after eliminating the other possibilities.
